Bouteille avec Patrick. Une robe orangée tuilée qui ne fit pas de mousse. Un nez intense danis et bourbon, de mélasse verte, boisé, intense. Une bouche intense de bois sans être déguelasse, de lalcool, de caramel, un peu sucrée. Une finale sucrée fruitée agréable sur les épices.

Grosse bouteille partagée avec Yan. Au niveau de lapparence, cette bière est plutôt ambrée. Le col beige se transforme assez rapidement en anneau. Au nez, beaucoup de choses qui sont pour le moins cohésives : bois, bourbon, épices, sirop dérable, vanille, mélasse. Ça sannonce tout en sucre ce truc. La première gorgée révèle du sirop dérable, de la vanille et du bourbon caramélisé. La deuxième et les suivantes ne font que confirmer le tout. En bouche, voila un corps de bonne densité avec une texture sirupeuse et une présence contrôlée des bulles. En finale, cest doux mais vite rattrapée par une chaleur dalcool qui empêche toute une catastrophe sucrée. Définitivement une assez bonne bière qui est fabriquée pour le partage entre amis.

750 mL bottle shared with ebone1988. Had this one before, finally rating it. The pour is a dark dark ruby, tons of sediment lurking, with a light khaki colored head that falls to a film while offering some great lace. The aroma is beautiful. There is a wonderful dark fruit presence with molasses and a sweet maltiness. The barrel offers a great bourbon character and a lot of vanilla on the back end. It's a little boozy on the back, but really good. The flavor is damn good. There is some molasses and a lot of dark fruits up front. The booze is a little hot on the beginning, but it really mellows out as the other flavors move in. Maple is present here over the nose. The bourbon gives way in lieu of vanilla, molasses, dark fruits, and a beautiful malt. The mouth feel is spot on. There is a great viscous creaminess and a soft carbonation that lets it stick to the palate. The aftertaste is lingeringly warming and full of vanilla and molasses and a touch of maple. Damn.

Transfer from BA review on 5-8-14-

 Poured from bottle into a snifter

 Appearance  The beer pours a crystal clear deep amber color with a one finger head of off white foam. The head fades rather fast leaving a great level of foamy lace on the sides of the glass. The thick body of the brew is foreshadowed by swirling the brew in the glass, as one can see thick fingers of liquid clinging to the sides with them very slowly settling back to the bottom of the snifter.

 Smell  A big caramel aroma is present in the nose with other sweet smells of vanilla and toffee. Some maple syrup and darker fruits aromas are present as well, upping the sweetness of the brews aroma. Along with the big sugary sweet smells comes along plenty of hot boozy smells with a strong bourbon and woody smell.

 Taste  The taste begins just as the nose would have suggested; with a big sweet caramel flavor. Right from start there is also a maple syrup flavor as well as some bready tastes. Some darker fruit flavors of raisin and plum with some other roasted malt taste also quickly come to the tongue with the mix of flavors largely acting as a base for the brew. As the flavor advances from the initial, it gains a bit of butterinesss with the caramel transitioning to a toffee flavor to some extent. Boozy flavors of a rum like nature start coming to the tongue more toward the middle of the taste, starting out lighter, but by the end of the taste growing rather strong. Other flavors of a more woody and oaky nature really pick it up toward the end of the taste, and with a surge of the maple syrup and a light bourbon flavor joining the rum, one is left with a very warming and rather sweet flavor to linger on the tongue.

 Mouthfeel  The body of the beer is thicker and sticky with a carbonation level that is on the lower side. Both are very nice for the sugary sweet (caramel, toffee, maple syrup) and boozy flavor of the brew and make for a very nice slow sipper.

 Overall  A robustly sweet and very tasty beer indeed. Tons of sugary tastes with a moderate dose of booze present as well, but yet still managing to maintain a decent balance for the style.

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2014 [Bottle / 1 year old] Deep amber tones with copper highlights, very nice clarity from top to bottom. The cap has an eggshell tint to it, lasting for a decent amount of time & leaving a little bit of lacing on its way down. Huge, robust aroma on this one; smooth bourbon, rustic oak, vanilla, mild black licorice, juicy dark fruit, booze-soaked figs & raisins, sweet toffee, molasses, & a wonderful kiss of maple syrup bringing up the rear. Strong, boozy, warming, & powerful. The taste has even more figs, raisins, & dates, soaked in bourbon & dipped in a brown sugar bath, drizzles with molasses & old maple syrup. Sticky toffee in the finish with a huge bourbon presence, plenty of oak, & a wonderful vanillin induction. Make no mistake - this is a HEAVY beer that seems even bigger than 11.9% ABV (even being one year old)... but I thought the flavors were on point, & this was just the improvement the regular Old Ale needed. Bravo!

1300th review!  750 ml bottle into snifter, bottled in 2/2012.  Pours lightly hazy ruby red color with a 1 finger dense cream colored head with good retention, that reduces to a thin lacing cap that lasts.  Spotty foamy lacing clings on the glass.  Aromas of big caramel, maple syrup, bourbon, raisin, fig, molasses, toast, toffee, brown sugar, herbal earthiness, oak, leather, pepper, light vanilla, and light coconut.  Fantastic aromas with great complexity and balance of barrel character and malt notes; hardly any alcohol presence.  Taste of big caramel, molasses, maple syrup, toast, toffee, bourbon, raisin, fig, vanilla, oak, pepper, herbal earthiness, leather, and light coconut.  Lingering notes of caramel, maple syrup, molasses, toast, toffee, raisin, fig, bourbon, vanilla, oak, pepper, leather, and herbal earthiness on the finish for a while.  Fantastic balance and complexity of robust malt flavor with well balanced barrel character; and zero cloying sweetness present after the finish.  Medium carbonation and very full bodied; with a very creamy, slick, and thick mouthfeel that is nice.  Alcohol is well hidden with only a small warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is a fantastic barrel aged old ale.  Fantastic complexity and balance of malt and barrel flavors; and moderately smooth to sip on.  A highly enjoyable slow sipper.

On tap at Churchkey in Washington DC, served in a snifter. Pours clear amber with a small, off-white head that remains and leaves a small amount of lace. On the nose, there are plenty of malts, along with spicy, oaky, fruity notes. The flavour is quite sweet, complex honey-maple-caramel with oaky overtones and a slight grainy note. There is also a hint of flowers. The barrel rounds it out nicely. The finish is long and malty with distinct barrel notes. On the palate, it is medium in body with a smooth, syrupy texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is a great old ale that is much improved by barrel ageing--it becomes smoother and more subtle than the base beer. 2012-06-09

Backlogged rating: Tap @ brewery (pre Better Half ): Chilled haze coppery hue with a very small fading head. The aroma has notes of heavy booze and sweet malts, intense caramel, vanilla, molasses, marizpan, maple oatmeal, white pepper and oak. The taste is very sweet and alcoholic with rye rewd, oatmeal, caramel, toast, vanilla bean and maple notes. Spicy and warming finish with a medicinal aftertaste. The mouth feel is oily and lush, medium to heavy body. Really? I like a nicely aged Curmudgeon much better. Just too sweet and too boozy!

Bottle at The Others Tasting, London - courtesy of Bruce. Pours clear ruby with modest sediment and some creamy head. Sugary malt nose with light cocoa and sugary fruits. Big sweet flavor with rich bread, light cocoa, hints of maple syrup. A bit medicinal and slightly artificial. Full bodied with fine to average carbonation. Warm finish with some raw alcohol, booze-soaked berries, sugary bread. OK. I love Founders, but this beer and the Frangelic Mountain Brown have hade a certain cheapness to them that has not impressed me. A reasonably tasty beer overall, but I expect more from this brewery.

As Better Half. Bottle @ THE Others Tasting. Thanks to Bruce for bringing this along! The pours deep reddish brown with a small head. Plenty of sediment in the pour. The nose is cherries, maple bar, red fruits and brown sugar sweetness. The taste is moderately hoppy, singed grass bitterness. More maple syrup and brown sugar, caramel. Somewhat light body. Fine carbonation. Overall, a very simple tasting beer. Still, it has its charms. Not bad.

Bottle (as Founders Curmudgeon Better Half), thanks to Bruce at THE others tasting. It pours clear deep amber with a small yellowish head. The nose is wood, varnish, hint of maple, raisin, honey, vanilla and toasted coconut. The taste is wood, alcohol warmth, dark fruit, raisin, sultana, honey, maple, spice and some bitterness with a dry, woody finish. Medium-full body, fine-prickly carbonation and sticky mouth-feel. Decent enough, but pretty hot and doesnt quite have the body to carry it off. Ok.
Bottle. Red deep golden colour  with an off-white head. Aroma is maple syrup, bourbon, vanilla, caramel, sugar.Flavour is vanilla, oak, bourbon, vanilla, caramel, sugar, alcohol. Very nice beer.

Bottle.  Pours lighter than expected, a dark semi-clear orange with minimal head.  Smell is light bourbon, oak, vanilla.  Taste is sweet but not cloying; maple/honey, sticky malts, toffee, dark fruits.  In the end the maple mixed with the fruity malts where a bit odd.  Slight a nice beer and the booze is extremely well  hidden, but this a bit of a dissapointment considering I have loved everything else that Founders has done.  Still a 3.6 doesnt suck, just lower than I would have thought prior to popping the top.

Bottle (750 ml) labeled as Curmudgeons Better Half. Traded by heyta, thanks Mark! Clear reddish brown with a small almost completely disappearing off-white head and nice lacing. Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, molasses, maple syrup, spices, dark fruits and caramel. Taste is moderately sweet with strong notes of bourbon, vanilla, molasses, maple syrup, spices, caramel and slight bitterness. Medium body and oily mouthfeel. Despite the important bourbon present, this beer isnt overly boozy. Very complex and superb use of the maple syrup bourbon barrels. Serious stuff! Definitely better than Curmudgeons Old Ale and taste like a more complex and balanced Backwood Bastards.

This draft brew from rbsg #6 poured a small sized head of foamy fine to medium sized off-white colored bubbles that were mostly lasting and left behind a hazy golden copper brown colored body and a good lacing. The mild aroma was old ale hoppy and malty. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish. The flavor contained notes of old ale wood mildly vinous and hops. Delicious and one I would certainly like to have again.

Bottle.  THe pour is copper with little head, fades quickly.  The aroma is very boozy with some sweetness hidden as well.  The taste is mostly bourbon upfront, but very smooth at the same time.  Finishes rather clean.  An overall outstanding beer.

750 ml bottle (Better Half) via trade with fatknitty - Pours a hazy deep amber color with a 2/3 finger thick off white head.  very light spotty lacing.  Aroma is toasted malt, maple, light molasses, and bourbon.  Flavor is the same with the addition of vanilla.  Finish is fairly smooth and the 11.9 % ABV is not overbearing.  Full body.  A good beer.  Thanks Joe.

Bottle 750ml. [ As Founders Curmudgeon Better Half ].[ Courtesy of Secret Summer Santa ]. Clear medium orange amber colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting to diminishing, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, maple, wood, alcohol notes. Flavour is heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a long duration, maple, alcohol, bourbon - vanilla notes, wood notes. Body is medium to full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft, finish feel is light alcoholic. Very tastefull and complex .. [20121109]

This was part of the awesome line-up at Capones Thanksgiving bash, where it was called Founders Better Half, and was the best beer of the night imo.  It tastes like a barley wine with maple syrup, and just the right amount of hops.  The flavors come together wonderfully - a great brew!

The beer is amber colored and mildly hazy with a small white head. The aroma is the best aspect of the beer, in my opinion. Oak, vanilla, maple, sugar, syrup, booze. The flavor is complex and well done, albeit too sweet. This seems like a beer that will age gracefully. Lots of oak, sweet maple, vanilla. Alcoholic warmth in the finish. A few ounces of this beer is plenty. I am looking forward to opening another one of these further on down the road.

Boozy overripe orange, walnuts. Cloudy orange, full of floaties, medium yellow head. Overripe orange, triple sec. Very boozy.
Draft at Capones. pours clear saphire with litte head nose is mild bourbon, sweet aldehydes, and brown sugar. First sip is similar with boozy hot flavors. This beer needs a few years to age.
Pours an amber color with an aroma of vanilla, maple, bourbon, and molasses.  Molasses, maple, vanilla falvor with hint of bourbon.  Very nice beer!

Phenomenal smell of sweetness due to the molasses and syrup. 

Minimal carbonation. 

Very smooth for 11.9%ABV.

Bottle at Papsøs - Thanks. Clear red/brown - white head. Roasted, amber malts, fruity, bourbon, vanilla, some light tobacco, dried fruits, coconut, candy, bolcher, syrup sweetness, hay notes, light grainy notes, light boozy bite. OK.

750 ml bottle received in trade. Thank you boltz7555! Cracked open to celebrate our first attempted brewing. Pours slightly hazy amber with a rather small offwhite head that leaves some trace and lacing on the glass while dissipating. Smell is sweet and intense with sweet caramel, bourbon, home made vanilla fudge, maple syrup, moist wood, slightly roasted coconut, caramelized roasted almonds, pecan nuts, American style pancakes with clotted cream and maple syrup, high quality toffee, milk chocolate and hay. Taste is sweet, very tiny bitter and malty with soft vanilla fudge, bourbon, brazil nut fudge, warming alcohol, caramel, maple syrup, battered egg, sweet dark bread, French toast, American style pancakes, warming alcohol, buttery wood, resin, bourbon, pecan nuts, toffee, burnt sugar, raisins, milk chocolate and subtle hints of cookie dough. Mouthfeel is round, slightly sticky sweet, very tiny astringent, tiny warming boozy and near full bodied. Finish is sweet, tiny bitter and malty with sweet dark bread, vanilla fudge, caramelized nuts, charred wood, maple syrup, coconut milk, cookie dough, hay and bourbon. If this beer is any indication our newly brewed pale ale will be great.

(Bottle) Pours light hazy copper red with a creamy, sand coloured head. The aroma holds tons of vanilla and caramel up front with undertones of nuts, pancakes, maple syrup, wood shop, coconut ice cram, butter, nectar, bananas, a touch of fruits, toffee,  tobacco and a whisper of grain Round nose with a light alcohol warmth. The flavour is medium sweet, light to medium bitter and tiny acidic with notes of white oak/bourbon, nuts, deep caramelized malt, subtle hops and fruity notes. The mouthfeel is round, soft and light sticky with light carbonation. Lingering malty and woodsy finish. Medium to full bodied.

Bottle at Papsø.
Clear orange coloured with small floaties and a small off-white head.
Sweet and fruity aroma of caramel, dried fruits, oak and vanilla.
Sweet and fruity flavour of caramel, dried fruits, oak and vanilla.
Sweet and warming alcoholic finish.

Bottle.  Mostly clear reddish amber beer with a small off-white head.  Aroma is caramel, apple, orange peel, maple, molasses, bourbon, wood.  Taste is very sweet, mild bitter, somewhat weak/boring but enjoyable.  Finish is both sweet and bitter, with a little spice and some alcohol.  Medium bodied, soft carbonation, very silky texture.
Bottled. An amber beer with a lazing beige head. The aroma has notes of cloves, caramel, and malt. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, caramel, and cloves, leading to a dry finish.

shared by papsoe.
clear reddish amber, small white head.
aroma of wood, syrup, sugar, woody spices. quite sweet.
flavor is quite sweet, booze, syrup , honey, lots of wood, bourbon. a bit too much.

UPDATED: APR 18, 2013 Bottled. Dark orange with an off white head. Very peculiar almost coconut-like aroma, probably from the bourbon barrels. It almost reminds me of marzipan. Taste has some of the same notes, it is quite sweet with a sticky mouthfeel and a heavy alcoholic note. To sip in small amounts.

Bottled. Amber coloured. Unclear. Dense beige head. Aroma: Spice, fruits, bourbon, wood marzipan. Flavour: Sweetness, vanilla, bourbon, brown sugar, wood, fruits, spice. Medium to full bodied. ends full of bourbon and vanilla. quite nice.

Bottle 75 cl. Courtesy of Doodler. Comes as "Founders Curmudgeons Better Half". Pours a hazy amber with a small off-white head. Rich, sweet caramel aroma with loads of sweet, smooth Bourbon. Rich body, sweet, sticky caramel, loads of vanilla and sweet wood. Quite some warming alcohol. Delicious, but probably hard to drink an awful lot of. 131112

Bottle from Chris Whittle. Copper pour with a thick bubbly head. Aroma is vanilla, sweet maple and molasses. Taste is mild sweetness with a slight bourbon and oak finish. Medium carbonation. Good old ale.

Bottle 750ml @ fonefan
Pours clear deep golden with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, maple syrup, vanilla and wood. Taste is medium to heavy sweet and light bitter with a long sweet, wood, vanilla and caramel finish. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Bottle, 75cl. An almost clear one, lighlty sparkling and amber in color and with a small off-white head. Lovely sugary, syrypy I guess, aroma with dried fruits, caramel, piney hops and a touch of alcohol. Quite complex, and that goes for the flavor too. Lots of sweetness showing up in the mouth after the swallow, with a fine bitterness, lots of dried fruits, some caramel and alcohol. A quite lovely one, damn tasteful and complex. 121109

Bottle, 11.9% @ FOneFan. Clear amber with small off-white head. Aroma is malt, caramel, fruit, little toffee and oak. Flavour is malt, caramel, toffee, sweet, oak, warming, vanilla, bourbon, maple syrup, little sugar,

Bottle @ fonefan tasting. As Founders Curmudgeons Better Half. Hazy reddish amber with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, maple syrup, vanilla and bourbon. Flavor is very sweet and moderate bitter. Very sweet finish with heavy alcohol. 091112
Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are rich vanilla, syrup, molasses, fruits, marzipan, almonds and hops.

Bottle - 750mL crowned under the "Curmudgeons Better Half" moniker. Translucent copper-ruby pour with a short, dense tan head. Very sweet aroma with strong maple syrup notes, light coconut, vanilla, sweet malt, caramel, oak notes, booze and soft molasses. Taste is very sweet and dessert-like. Lots of maple syrup, vanilla, molasses, caramel, rum cake, booze, soft fruit notes, wet oak, soft, toasted coconut, and brown sugar. Body is medium-full and rather syrupy with a soft, creamy carbonation, moderate warmth and lots of stickiness. Finishes with more caramel, vanilla, maple syrup, molasses, brown sugar, sweet malt, sponge cake and booze.

A - Pours a cloudy red-orange with a finger of frothy off-white head. The head fades down fairly quickly leaving behind some nice lacing.

S - Aroma is sweet caramelized malts with vanilla, oak, Bourbon, maple syrup, some dark fruits, brown sugar, molasses, and a bit of booze.

T - Starts off with sweet caramelized malts, vanilla, brown sugar, black licorice, and dark fruits. Through the middle, lots of oak, Bourbon, and maple syrup come through with some molasses. The finish is a mix of sweet caramelized malts, oak, vanilla, maple syrup, Bourbon, molasses, and a bit of booze.

M - Full bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth with a sweet and warming finish.

D - Very drinkable. The maple Bourbon barrels really add some great complexity to the beer while keeping the balance spot on.

On tap at Sharp Edge Creekhouse. Light roast and nutty aromas. Roasted barley, chocolate malt, mildly sweet. Dark coppery brown clear with light haze, topped with thin lacing off-white head. Medium-heavy body, not quite oily, with soft carbonation. Starts sweet with roasted barley, chocolate, oak, licorice, brown sugar, and tannic bitterness. Alcohol warming, rich earthy bitterness. Dry bitter after with alcoholic sweetness and bitter chocolate.

750ml bottle shared in line at DLD. Thanks to either khumbard or cpmichael! Served in a Deschutes tulip.

A: Pours a hazy golden amber with deep rosy hues in the body. There are a lot of floaties in this guy. No real head forms on the pour, just a thin film that recedes to tiny ring. It leaves some splotches behind.

S: Leather and tobacco mix nicely with some light oak and bourbon. Dark fruits, mainly dates and figs are also present with the slightest hint of maple.

T: The maple syrup really shows itself in the taste. Its very sweet, but its balanced by the light bourbon and oak. Also some nice dark fruits and pale malts show themselves. Smalls hints of tobacco.

M: Medium bodied and medium carbonation. Sweet syrup finish that is a tad dry.

O: It was really sweet from the maple and the boubon took a back seat, but it was very good overall and the booze was very well hidden. I see this syndrom appearing with CBS as well where the bourbon isnt that present and the maple sort of takes over. Either way, both are great.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-02-2012

750ml bottle traded with grachdar. Thanks!

A: Frail copper with a clean white head. Falls off the glass.

N: Malt and pineapple. Thik, dripping caramel. Maple and vanilla.

T: Butterscotch and toffee. Burnt brown sugar and caramel. This is surprisingly biting. Bourbon is faint here. Cotton candy. Alcohol is very well hidden.

M: Pleasantly heavy. Carbonation level is very good - not faint, but not dominant

O: Pretty good, but not amazing. Its really straddling the line betwen, burnt sugar, bitterness, and sweetness. Recommended, but might benefit from age.

Shared 750 ml. Ruby pour with a small off white head. Big sweet bourbon nose with brown sugar and dark fruits. Med body with vanilla, syrup, apples and dark fruits. Warming finish with dark fruits, bourbon and sugar.
Pours a red-amber with practically no head. Aroma of sweet maple. Taste is a bit astringent with the bourbon and extra alcohol but still good to sip on.

Bottle pours a murky, sediment filled orange/red color with a tiny off white head. Scent is malty, wood, caramel and booze. Taste is sweet malts, vanilla, wood and caramel. Tasty! Thanks to Ed for the bottle!

Amber brown pour with a full off white head and light lacing.  Huge full well coated and creamy palate.  Aroma lighter than expected sweet syrups almost a brown sugar quality some light alcohols.  Flavor is syruppy sweet some maple syrup notes caramels some vanilla and bourbon like notes with a hot alcoholic swallow.  Good but I couldnt drink much of it as the sweetness becomes overwhelming.

2012 bottle poured into a tulip glass, dark amber with a 1" white head. Nose is butterscotch, bourbon, caramel, burnt sugar...typical old ale, but a little sweeter and a touch of bourbon. Very hot alcohol burn. A ton of yeast at the bottom of the bottle. Very nice old ale, would be interested to see what a little age would do for it.

Rating #2400. Bottle labeled "Better Half" from a trade with peteinSD. Peter sent me a bottle after I got screwed by a trader that never shipped, an awesome gesture. Pours hazy caramel color with off white head. Aromas of caramel, bourbon, molasses and bleu cheese. Sweet molasses flavor with vanilla, caramel, oak and bourbon. Medium body with soft carbonation. A nice sipper. Thanks Peter, a truly generous ratebeerian!

Bottle, shared at RBAG Summer Session 2012, under the "Better Half" label. Medium amber (for some reason I thought it would be darker), creamy off-white head that laces lightly. Strong maple syrup nose, which I love, some bourbon and vanilla. Interestingly, the maple takes a bit of a backseat on the palate, with bourbon whiskey more dominant, along with some vanilla, molasses; undercurrents of wood. Reading my review, youd expect this to be killer sweet, but somehow it wasnt. Surprisingly balanced, very nice.

text: RBAG Summer Session 2012. Dark brownish red with, thin white head, aroma has notes of maple, dark chocolate, hints of vanilla, dark fruits with a hint of maple and slight toffee. Taste is a mix of maple, dark fruit, some slight hint of roast, touch of biscuit, bread, finishing fairly sweet.
Not good at all. Maybe old bottle. Slight maple syrup taste, but mostly alcohol. Nothing special and will avoid in the future.

Bottle. Pours a hazy orange color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty woody caramel aroma. Sweetish malty woody vanilla flavor with hints of caramel. Has a sweetish malty woody vanilla and caramel finish.

Poured into a snifter. 

3.5 A: Well hazed plum color. Two fingers of frothy beige head. Retention is below average, even for the ABV, but a decent lattice of lacing is left.

4.5 S: The maple syrup is huge in this. Its about twice as potent as in CBS. Molasses follows, then raisin, plum, tobacco, and apple fruitiness. The bourbon influence is minimal, but it does add an extra layer of complexity along with some oak. Plenty of caramel and a bit of toffee. Smells great and the alcohol is well hidden.

3.5 T: The taste is taken over by raisin and tobacco, which even pushed aside the maple syrup. Following those, molasses, plum, apple, oak, and maple syrup are found. The bourbon is a good bit stronger in the taste and it brings along a booziness that is expected with a 12% brew. The reason that I dont like this more is because it is pretty damn sweet. Not Bruery sweet, but sweeter than it needs to be. Otherwise, it is tasty.

3.5 M: Heavy body. Good moderate carbonation. Reasonably creamy, but its a bit syruppy as well and gives a hefty chewiness.

3.5 D: Its tasty, but I wish it fermented out a bit more. Love the flavors, but just too much sweetness.

Serving type: bottle

2700th rating. 750mL bottle, sent from ChiTownPackFan (thanks a lot Will). Pours a hazy orangey gold wit a small white head. Aroma of bourbon barrels, molasses, vanilla and slight maple syrup - quite decadent. Flavour brings out vanilla upfront, with notes of bourbon, oak and marzipan. Very complex and bordering on too sweet, but quite cloying. ABV is very well-concealed. Body is quite light all things considering. Very enjoyable slow sipper.

Bottle. Pours a cloudy orange with small beige head. The aroma is oak, maple syrup, and vanilla. Medium mouthfeel with a strong molasses and vanilla flavor with maple syrup. Alcohol present but not overpowering with a nice sweet finish. A very impressive old ale from Founders.

rich amber pour, floaters, and a white/cream head.  nose is hops, right malts, caramel, dried fruits, and vanilla.  thick and chewy on the palate, caramel, vanilla, wood, light sherry, and alcohol in the finish.

75 cL bottle as Founders Better Half. Pours hazy orange with a small white head. Aroma is spiced, dark malty and dense caramelish. Sweet toasted caramelish. Smooth malty and sweet into a caramelish finish. Smooth caramelish malty finish.

Pours orange-ruby into a snifter. Bright white dead with little retention recedes lavying scant lacing. Maple and bourbon aromas. Medium bodied with sweet molasses and hot maple bourbon front to back. Warm lasting maple syrup finish.

Aroma- onslaught of bourbon, molasses, maple, barrel qualities, oak, vanilla
Appearance- hazy orange, intense amount of sediment floating around, low carbonation
Taste- super sweet bourbon, maple syrup, vanilla, oak, slight tobacco, booze
Palate- full-bodied with a slick mouthfeel
Overall- As expected, a world-class brew from Founders.  A sipper for sure, the only detracting factor was the unappealing look due to the sediment.  Fantastic!

Poured from a bottle sent by Tooch4321. Thanks! Poured into a brandy snifter at room temperature. Pours a ruddy brown color, nearly the color of rust. Almost no head or carbonation. In the aroma I get some complex raisin, figs, bourbon, molasses, and sherry notes. The taste was initially a kick in the face and primarily bourbon. The barrel really took this beer over. I tried the beer by itself at first, and then paired it up against regular Old Curmudgeon, and then had a cigar with all of them. In this case, regular Old Curmudgeon won my vote. Thankfully the cigar pairing toned down the bourbon notes and made Better Half much more enjoyable for me.If I had another bottle of this, Id trade it away in a heartbeat.
Dark and rich.  Molasses and maple sweetness, but the dominant flavor comes from the bourbon barrels. Sticky mouthfeel, raisin, and alcohol aroma.  Tried at the Cunigans tasting party in 2012.

Sampled at EBF. Old Ale with molasses and maple syrup bourbon barrels...yeah Im all about it. First thing that really hit me up front was the sweetness and booze, followed by the molasses on the back end. A real treat!

UPDATED: AUG 5, 2012 750 ml to oversized snifter. Looks good; amber with thin lacing. Smells good too; sweet, maple, vanilla, and a bit of booziness. Tastes a lot like it smells, and has improved since the release  Mouthfeel is nice. Much better with some age on it.

Bottle from Sean - thanks!  Light amber red pour with a slick of tan foam.  Aroma is heavy, sweet malt, bourbon, vanilla, maple, and thick, dried fruit. Taste is mellow and sweet with bourbon, vanilla, and toffee, caramel and a bit of alcohol.  Clean, coating mouthfeel.  Excellent sipper and I need more.

Thanks to someone for sharing at bu11zeyes 10,000th rating tasting. 

The beer pours an orange-brown color with a tan head. The aroma is awesome. I get a lot of maple and oak notes, as well as some vanilla and toffee malt. The flavor is very similar. There is a lot of maple and vanilla from the barrel aging. I also get quite a bit of toffee and caramel malt, as well as some alcohol. Medium to thick mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

Cellared for awhile and finally opened today. Deep amber, dark orange. Smells of bourbon barrel aged goodness. Since slightly aged, the alcohol is strong, and stays in the background until it warms your mouth. Rich, thick and fragrant, full of notes of raisin, oak, bourbon, smooth and sweet. What a pleasure. Strong aromas with every sip.

Draft at The Pour House in Westmont, NJ. 

Pours a deep, dark burnt orange color with tangerine edges and a two finger, frothy yellowish-beige head that very slowly settles into a lasting ring.  Soapy lacing left behind.

Sweet boozy aroma with a pretty strong barrel presence.  Lots of earthy oak, maple and bourbon along with some leathery malts, toffee and hazelnut. Oak is strongest element which is surprising.  As it warns, the molasses character comes out and meshes nicely with the maple.  Still, the nose is surprisingly a bit bland with too strong of an oak presence for my liking.

Medium bodied with lots of boozy heat and a strong barrel presence.  Dominant dry oak flavor with booze and sweet maple notes.  Underneath, there is some more booze and leathery malt.  Sweetness kicks in as it warns with hints of toffee, caramel and hazelnut. Dry and spicy with subtle molasses.  Still pretty hot however and a bit harsh.  6oz is plenty.

4oz pour at Churchkey is a clear, burnt orange with some creamy, white head.  Nose of bourbon, booze, cinnamon, nutmeg, sour mash whiskey.  Flavor is like a boiler maker, malty, sweet, booze, sour mash, rootbeer candies, vanilla, caramel.  Full bodied, boozy finish.

Bottle. Clear dark goldish pour with a bit of white head and a ton of floaties. Aroma is distinctly maple forward, some alcohol, quite malty, some molasses, vanilla and bourbon. Taste is rich and sweet, lots of maple syrup, discreet bourbon flavors, not much perceptible alcohol. Palate is rich and sticky, medium carbonation. A bit too sticky but delicious and dessert-like. Good stuff.
Pale reddish brown color, slight orange. Flavor is boozy and sweet, like. Grand Marnier. Some maple syrup, bit very light and not overly sweet. Very classy tasting.

Had on tap at a Philly Beer Week event in 2012. Rebranded as "Curmudgeons Better Half". This beer had all the malty complexity Ive ever wanted in an old ale. It had a great scent of bourbon, molasses, and maple. The taste was rich but clean. It didnt linger on the palate too long. Definitely one of the top 5 beers Ive ever had. Underrated next to the CBS in my opinion.
On tap at Capones. Poured a brownish, amber color with a small sized head. Aromas of caramel, vanilla, bourbon, and maple. Tastes of caramel, vanilla, maple, sugary, and molasses. Sweeter.

On tap @ Carpones.  Poured a deep dark brown with reddish hues, minimal head and lacing.  Huge aroma of bourbon, vanilla oak, plum, and a hint maple syrup.  Taste is sweetness in the form of butterscotch, molasses, raisin, and caramel malts followed by piney hops before a surprisingly smooth finish with minimal alcohol warmth.

labeled under Curmudgeon Better Half poured a nice rich amber with a light tan head. aroma alcohol, bourbon, brown sugar, vanilla, malt, pine, after sitting in my glass for about 10 min. the some of the alcohol diminished . flavor cheap bourbon with sugar, maple,  lightly sour, strange spices. this was a waste of 15.00. Very close to a drain pour
Glad to have the opportunity to try this. Def a sweeter beer from the maple syrup bourbon barrel. A step up from the curmudgeon.  Great smoothness on the palate.

Appearance: Pours a deep dark ruby with a 1/8 inch head of white. Leaves spotty lacing.

Aroma: Spicy malt, maple sugar, faint but noticeable alcohol, booze soaked pear.

Taste: Maple sugar, bourbon barrel, dark chocolate, burnt caramel. Dark fruit. Spicy hops. Finishes warm.

Mouthfeel: Full bodied warming.

Overall:  A truly delicious Old Ale/Barleywine.  Very complex, with each tasty component having the ability to shine.  If you have some to cellar away, go for it, but this was ready for prime time when I cracked it.

on draft. poured a reddish/brown color. minimal head. the aroma was amazing. you picked up the bourbon barrel, the maple, bits of vanilla, the old ale alcohol. the flavor was right in line...strong bourbon hints and maply syrup. totally amazing flavors with each sip. wish i had more of this one.

750mL bottle pours deep clear amber with tall dark tan head. The aroma is all over the place initially with boozy heat giving way to vanilla, sweet bourbon, molasses and then an odd mix of pine hops and sweet malts. The taste is bold with vanilla and bourbon and surrounded by thin rings of molasses and pine hop bitterness. It gets a bit more molasses but bold firm sweet bourbon booze quickly overshadows it. With all the cool flavors the beer aspect of this drink has; it is a shame too much barrel time has pretty much wiped them out. Way way too barrel forward and when I think about all the rich beer flavors Im missing and all the potential this beer has with less barrel time it makes me weep and angry all at the same time. Ok, let me put my purse down and grab a tissue so I can have a good cry.

Bottle as "Better Half" thanks to ktown67. Pours with a clear bronze body with minimal head and some particles. Aromas are of honey, molasses, maple and bourbon. Syrupy, sweet, caramel and boozy. Flavors are of cereal, malty, maple, molasses, bourbon, toasted coconut, vanillin, and alcohol. Quite warming, medium bubbles, syrupy, good.

Bomber, pours honeyed amber w/ dense off-white head, huge aroma of molasses, burnt sugar, and butterscotch, flavor is major butterscotch, more molasses and burnt sugar throughout, full, rich and luxurious, really an amazing brew

750 @dmacs willblake is back in NJ tasting-thanks Scott pours amber with an offwhite head.  Aroma is sweet medium malt, spice-nutmeg, slight alcohol.  Taste is sweet medium malt-caramel, spice-nutmeg, 2nd earthy hops, alcohol.

Tap (shaker pint) at OB Noodle House. Clear brownish auburn with a one finger creamy off-white head, great retention. Bourbon and oak up front in the nose, some sweet maple and toasty malts follow.
Flavor continues with the sweet bourbon--I get more maple than molasses-with some added toasty malts and sweet raisin notes. Dry finish, bitterness at a 3, alcohol masked well--11.9%?!?  Id guess it at 8%. Full body with mod carbonation. Not overly complex, but tasty. Pleasantly surprised this was on--apparently the Nood has ordered 21 kegs from Founders, including the KBS!
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Bottle @ home. JetsonFest II. Fairly clear, dark reddish appearance with a cream head. Rich caramel, a bit herbal, maple, dull hoppy aroma. Rich maple, thick toffee, somewhat herbal hoppy, molasses, caramel flavor. Sure its fun to try bu theres nothing special about this mofo.
Bottle. Aroma - maple syrup, bourbon barrel.  Flavor - maple syrup, chocolate, bourbon barrel.

Pour out of 750 mL bottle, thanks to Aaron for the pour! Dark brownish red with, thin white head, aroma has notes of maple, dark chocolate, hints of vanilla, dark fruits with a hint of maple and slight toffee.   Taste is  a  mix of maple, dark fruit, some slight hint of roast, touch of biscuit, bread, finishing fairly sweet.
Pours an orange-amber color with an off-white head.  Aroma has bourbon, caramel and some maple.  Taste is sweet with noticeable maple.  Thin bodied and sticky.  Smooth, but a little hot.

Tap at Glass Nickel for Madisons Craft Beer Week. Pours mahogany with dark purple/garnet highlights. Thin tan head. Not much lacing to speak of, but nice alcohol legs on the glass. Huge vanilla/bourbon notes on the nose, plum candy and booze. Sweet, maple goodness follows on the tongue, with more bourbon and vanilla bean. Mild hop astringency. A little hot, and I get the hesitation to embrace this beer, but man did I enjoy it.

Had as Better Half .. . Pours a deep gold amber .. white foam, low strength lacing .. . lots of sweet honey wine, maple syrup and golden booze .. . wow, so out of whack, very boozy .. this needs at least 3-5 years to be great and i think it has the potential .. . . PMS jokes arent funny, period.
On tap at Sugar Maple.  Hazed ruby red with a receding tan head.  Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, oak and sweet malt.  Taste is boozy with bourbon, vanilla, oak and caramel.

75cl, as Curmudgeons Better Half, new exclusive American brew Anno 2012, with maple syrup, thx to Secret Santa!, very complex brew, sweet/alcoholic and slightly fruity/spicy, heavy, yet balanced, cloudy, good head, very good brew, yet very expensive!

Poors golden with a white head.  Taste is sweet, vanilla, and bourbon.  No bitterness and is more like a desert beer.  This is really good and goes down quick for such a high % beer.  If you can get your hands on it give it a try.

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2012 from Hunahpus. The alcohol is there to say hi but there are some tasty flavors mixed in. Maple, caramelized sweet, raisin/slight sherry, 
re-rate: had to bump it up a couple points. dry finish, tasty

Clear amber pour thin off white head .... Aroma of bourbon, maple syrup, caramel, vanilla, light butterscotch ... taste is of vanilla, bourbon, maple syrup/molasses, vanilla, caramel malts, butterscotch and light bitter hops .... mouthfeel is viscous definitely a heavy hearty brew the maple syrup really lingers on the taste bud, thick and molasses like .... abv is slightly noticable but hidden pretty well ... bitter bite and dry syrupy finish to it .... good sipping brew or to pour on pancakes  ... thanks shueyy for sharing

Sampled from a 750 ml brown bottle this beer poured an orange-brown color with a medium sized soapy and creamy orange-tan head that lingered and left decent lacing. The aroma was sour and tangy molasses, caramel, raisin and pineapple. The flavor was boozy with notes of raisin, molasses, maple and pineapple. Medium length sour and tangy finish with lingering raisin and maple. Moderately full bodied. Boozy but not overwhelmingly so. Very nice.

Clear dark amber to mahogany color with a decent sized white tan head, ok retention and lacing... bourbon wood kinda sweet dark fruits cherry vanilla malty aroma... Sweet flavor, raisin molasses syrupy malty up front mellows into a bourbony vanilla finish with notes of dark fruit that is quite boozy... complexish... very very full bodied not very carbonated... boozy...

Deep sweet aroma with faint wood some bourbon, syrup, vanilla and toffee. Maybe caramel.  Big maple for sure. Good color  no head and unfiltered. Ominous and murky red gold. White circle stays as it drains. Sweet but not too sweet. Aspects of make it seem like a barrel aged barleywine. Slightly boozy, but its nice. Sweet boozy maple with bourbon and a concise finish. Sweetness doesnt linger. World class.

750mL bottle courtesy of Jason.  Cheers, sir!  Pours a caramel brown with a white head.  Nose is maple, toffee, vanilla, wood, lots of malt, and a bit of booze secure in the loving arms of this toffee-heavy beer.  Flavor is similar with maple, toffee, vanilla, bourbon, some chocolate, and a balance that seems to have developed recently.  I really enjoyed this beer.
(750ml bottle)  Pours an amber-brown body with a medium off-white head.  Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, maple, and caramel.  Flavor of bourbon, molasses, wood, maple, toffee, and vanilla.

Bottle. Poured a dark nutty orange. Head reduced to a thin ring with some flotsam just under the surface. Heavy bourbon and maple flavors. Rich vanilla bourban sweetness. Body feels a bit thin when cold, but butters up as it warms. High alcohol is not hidden, but the deep flavors make it easy to sip.

Thanks to Marc Nolan for this, Dark Ammber pour with a tan head. Aroma is maple,  leather, molasses and bourbon. Tate is very mellow, deliscious. Sweet but not overbearing. Maple, alcohol, leather. It is much better than Curmudgean itself. Creamy at the end. OK lacing.

Tap at DLD 2012. Bright orange In color with a small bit of white head and minimal carbonation.  I had the regular Curmudgeon the night before and thought it was great, but this went to another level. Intense flavors of vanilla, bourbon and hints of maple with a touch of hops. Damn near perfection!

Tap at DLD 12.  Read other reviews for details.  Just know that if you ever get a chance to try it, pounce on the opportunity!  Absolutely amazing brew.  One of the best things I ever tasted, liquid or solid.

Ive been curious to try this for a while, and was able to get a hold of a snifter just last night at Barcade in Jersey City.  Beer pours bright amber/orange, with a caramel toffee bourbon overtone.  Little head retention.  It also benefits from sitting and warming up - aromas open up more.  Attack is caramel and bourbon, some maple in there too.  Neat taste profile with some bourbon and caramel feel throughout.  Special beer!

The pour is amber in color with a white head.  Lots and lots of vanilla and maple aromas to this.  Caramel and toffee malt sweetness are well represented.  Minimal wood with a good dose of bourbon to it as well.  The flavor is just as wonderful.  Lots of bourbon, maple, vanilla, and caramel.  Maybe a little bit of brown sugar to go with it all.  A little bit of oak flavor and dark fruit.

bottle courtesy of hublovesbeer, thanks Dani!  curmudgeon is one of my favorite beers, i have been waiting years to try this! its really good, but overall i feel cbs is a little more interesting with the barrel and all. the curmudgeon is already sweeter, so it is a little harder to pick up on the barrel subtleties for me. very nice aroma, and the taste is a meshing of sweet bourbon, maple, malts and then the classic curmudgeon. overall i expected to like it a little bit more. its a great beer, and probably better fresh.
Draft courtesy of GT2, thank you sir!  This is definitely a big beer, with lots of vanilla, caramel, whiskey. Some dark fruits lurking in the background. Decent.

Tap at Bier Baren. Clear deeper amber. Small white bubbles. Thick bourbon nose with heat and vanilla, maple sugar, big richness. Taste with spicy, hot, fairly boozy one note with odd bitterness. A bit too hoppy which is odd. Somewhat medicinal with big sweetness and lingering long bitterness. Okay. Impossible to drink more than a few ounces. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma: toffee, vanilla, bourbon and earthy oak notes, brown sugar.  Pours amber/brown, thin off-white head, leaves little lacing.  Very rich flavor, lots of caramel and toffee, dark sugar, slightly fruity, vanilla and oak notes, bourbon, warming alcohol, hints of maple syrup.  Starts out a little sharp but mellows as it warms.  Full body, low-medium carbonation.  Really nice brew.

Bottle, thanks, Brian. Pours amber/orange, with an off white head. Aroma is malt, maple syrup, bourbon, vanilla, and some fruit. Flavor is bourbon, malt, vanilla, and maple syrup. Medium body. Not as thick or sweet as I expected.

Bottle shared by rschanke...thanks Rob! - Pours amber with a thin tan head. Nose is pretty sharp, with a bit of cherry, some sweet malt--but mostly booze. Taste is much better. The heat recedes, and the maple comes forward. Sweet, but fairly restrained. Nice and bready, with a mellowness to it. Not much carbonation, and pretty slick. Okay, but I cant see going crazy over this beer.

Wonderful.  750 ml Bottle at Waldos Pizza in Kansas City. AROMA: oak and bourbon, traces of caramel and very light molasses; APPEARANCE: deep dark brown,  great full bodied head dissipating more quickly than Id have thought; TASTE: Sweet but clear taste with strong bourbon, very rich; PALATE: full bodied, creamy texture, long sweet finish.
bottle at bu11zeye 10k, amber copper color with off white foam, aroma of orange peel and maple syrup, flavor of caramel, citrus, syrupy hot finish

Bomber bottle from my neighbor Bob with my thanks for allowing me to enjoy this fantastic ale.  Superlatives are not adequate in describing anything about this, simply stated, this is one of the best beers on the market.  Close you eyes and you might think youre drinking a bottle of bourbon --- its that rich in spirits.  Check the sediment at the finish and youll find floating remnants of the barrels its aged in waiting to be taken down with the dregs.
Bottle from ktown67.  Labeled as Better Half.  Amber pour with a small tan head.  Aroma is pancakes, baking spice, and alcohol.  Taste is spice, maple, and morning goodness.

(750ml bottle thanks to Ktown67) clear medium copper with wispy tan bubbles. Nose of caramel and brown sugar, honey, light hops. Taste of caramel, honey, sweet, bit of light hops. Medium body that is well carbonated.
TAP: Hazy deep redish brown. Bourbon, wood, maple syrup, brown sugar on the nose. Taste starts sweetly and mellows the bourbon.

Date: April 10, 2012 Mode: Tap Source: Happy Gnome Description: Translucent reddish brown pour with not much head though not sure how long before it was poured.  Aroma was bourbon, sweet maple and some wood.  Taste was consistent and palate was smooth and creamy.

Poured from a bomber.  Pours dark like cola with a bit of head, but not a ton.  Aroma is some maple and bourbon.  This reminds me a bit of BA4D, but a little less sweet.  A maple version of Backwoods Bastard.
UPDATED: DEC 30, 2013 Tap. Reddish brown pour with a white head. Nose is sweet maple syrup and oak. Full palate. Taste is oak, bourbon, and maple syrup. Yummy.

750ml bottle acquired via trade. Pours reddish/brown with a very small beige head. Aroma is dominated by maple syrup with some toffee, bourbon, oak and alcohol. Flavor is sweet maple and caramel with a boozy bourbon and oak heat. Medium body with mild carbonation and a sweet, syrupy mouth feel. This is a good beer but is all sweet maple and toffee against lots of boozy bourbon. Split a bottle with a few friends.

750 bomber shared with Hamilton23.  Dark maple pour with a decent amount of head.  Nose is over the top malty with vanilla, bourbon, and an ever so slight maple syrup hint.  Taste was equally over the top sweet malt with vanilla, toffee, and bourbon.  Awesome stuff.

on tap at bar great harry, brooklyn. $8 for an 8 ounce glass. I was willing to pay that for a chance to taste this rare beer, no problem. It was wonderful. definitely drink this if you get the chance. I expected a bit more, but i loved it all the same.

Deep amber with red-brown highlights.  Aroma of oak, coconut, light maple syrup, pineapple, and faint vanilla.  Flavor is caramelized fruit, tannin-wood, coconut, and sweet maple syrup.  Dry wood/barrel finish with some residual sugars/fruit.  Some noticeable alcohol that becomes a little less prevalent with continued sipping.  To me, this one could use some time in the cellar.  The wood/barrel aspects are still a bit raw.  The maple syrup/bourbon flavors do add to the beer, though, and should be great given some time.

Very smooth but kicker at the beginning. Feeling of burning scotch  rolling down throat on first sip. High ABV and soothing feeling. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft at Great Bar Harry. Aroma of Bourbon, no head. Sweet tasting with  upfront booze, this is hot! Some Vanilla, caramel, I find it too sweet and too  strong for my liking.

Bottle at Waldos Pizza.  Hazy medium brown with a fizzy white head.  Very nice sweet floral aroma of sugar and bourbon.  Tastes of caramel, vanilla, candy sugar, molasses, bourbon, and oak with some grain notes.  Very good.
Reddish pour, tan head and some floaties. Aroma is very sweet, some maple, oak, golden raisin. Flavor is sweet and boozy, oak, lightly bitter. Some maple notes. Nice! Thanks storminorman

Bottle shared by Scott at the willblake returns to NJ tasting. Poured a nice clear sunburnt orange amber body under a foamy super light beige head. Aroma is very similar to regular Curmudgeon, notes of vanilla extract, alochol, barrely, very light molasses. The body is full, syrupy and hot with softer carbonation. Flavor of dry vanilla, dry toast, wood, rum soaked cake. Meh, great beer but not that different from the regular Curmudgeon and Im not really getting the maple.

Reckless pour into a Southampton goblet.  Poured clear but, in the glass, a hazy, ruby hue.  Off-white head disspiates quickly leaving a ring of large bubbles that, actually, dont look too appealing.  The nose is much nicer!  Wood, dark sugar, molasses, bourbon faintly.  Very sweet up front.  Maple prevalent and mellows out the bourbon nicely.  Strong finishing sweetness with high levels of smackability.  Very, very tasty.

Crystal clear light chestnut pour with a razor-thin eggshell head.  Aroma is faint with fusel, vanilla, wood, and caramel.  Flavor also includes an abundance of alcohol accompanied by maple, toffee, honey, and biscuit.  First Founders in a while Ive been disappointed by.  Have another bottle that I will sit on and revisit later.  Right now, this is a bit of a hot mess.

Live rate!  Bottle generously shared by Boltz - thank you, sir!  Pous hazy copper with a trim beige head.  Smells of buttery blueberry pancakes.  Tastes of sweet malts, maple syrup, berries, and dry yeast.  Goes down easy.  Too easy.Earlier Rating: 8/7/2010 Total Score: 4.1On tap at Founders.  Looks gorgeous.  Pours a reddish caramel shade with a creamy beige head of sugary foam.  I got giddy every time I swirled this.  Smells a bit strange -- almost like theres cardamom in there.  Tastes predominately of toffee, cream, sweet citrus, and pineappley/Lagunitas-esque hops.  Interesting.

750ml bottle poured into a snifter. Pours black with about a finger of dark tan head. Aroma of maple syrup, whisky, vanilla and caramel. Taste is about the same. Its like getting drunk on a bourbon covered pancake. Full bodied with a thick and creamy texture. Soft carbonation and a very long finish. Overall, I really really like this beer. I would gladly drink this every day!

25.4 oz bottle.  Clearish maroon brown with a mottled tan head.  Nose is butterscotch, oak, maple and raisin.  Medium body with a tang and considerable heat.  Taste is caramel, scotch, vanilla, cinnamon spice and anise.  Still pretty hot and surprisingly straightforward.

On draft at the Royale. Pours very murky and amber with little to no head. Aroma is maple, caramel malts, light booze. Flavor is very sweet, maple, hints of booze. Light carbonation and medium bodied.

Curmudgeons Better Half . 750 ml bottle into a DFH signature glass. Big thanks to boilerbrew for the trade!

A - Clear dark red/orange body. 2 finger off-white head, very fluffy with large bubbles. Great lacing and retention.

S - I could smell the sweetness immediately after opening the beer. Super sweet toffee malts with lighter bourbon notes of vanilla and oak. A fruit aroma is also very present, I cant put my finger on it exactly buts is similar to a caramel apple. Some lingering dark fruits, brown sugar and molasses. I cant really detect any maple.

T - This beer starts off with a toffee malt flavor that youll find in any good old ale. This is followed by a super sweet yet smooth wave of molasses and maple. Complex notes of leather, oak, vanilla, and butterscotch finish the beer off. Lightly bitter with a huge sweetness present through the entire sip. Super decadent and rich but I dont find it to be cloying at all. Alcohol heat is present as it warms up but never offensive. Mouth feel is medium bodied and a bit syrupy with low carbonation. Matches the flavor profile perfectly.

O - Wow. This beer is phenomenal. Its just a delicious old ale that was barrel aged to perfection. Tons of sweetness with just the right amount of bourbon notes. Very smooth and complex. I really enjoyed this one.
Draft. Brown pour with tan head. Bourbon, maple, sweet malty aromas.  Nice full flavored sweet, maple, bourbon flavors. Full body, alcohol is well hidden.

After pouring into my seventeen ounce snifter, I am able to detect in descending intensity: caramel, leather, alcohol, butterscotch, vanilla, and woodiness.  The ale is a crystal clear amber with a two level head of frothiness topped by a much thinner layer of rocky tan bubbles.  A taste enforces the aromas and begins with medium sweetness and finishes only slightly bitter.  It has a medium body with a sticky texture.  The carbonation was quite lively initially, but it softened as it rested.  I am very happy I sprang for a bottle of the Curmudgeons Better Half, the name under which it was released, despite the fact that I could not really detect any maple syrup.  I presume the maple syrup influenced the development of this ale in other ways that have delighted my senses, despite not revealing itself directly.  When will Founders be releasing a Scotch ale aged in maple syrup bourbon barrels?

Pours a cloudy brownish purple orange. This beer is syrup sweet right now. I personally enjoy sweeter English style BWs, but this was even a bit much for me. I would be really interested to see how this beer drinks in a couple years. It could use a bit of oxidation IMO.

750 from PUBN.  Pours turbid deep dull coppery/Carolina mud color with 1-finger ecru head.  Nose is oaky spirity bourbon, maple, hops, molasses, fruit.  Tastes malty, with a big oaky and bourbony flavor upfront, some old aley yeasty esters at mid palate, and more fusel heat late.  As it warms, becomes like an old ale/cognac hybrid,m and I enjoyed every sniff and taste.  This one is big, complex, and just pounds you into submission with its greatness (thats what she said).

This rating is for the bottle which I thought was much better then kaiser last year and old curmudg on tap this year. Tons of cinnamon and vanilla, rich bourbon notes in aroma and the taste. Not much maple but its def in there. Very good. Where is Cashew Mountain in bottles guys?

750 ml bottle poured a clear reddish amber with a small lingering amber head. Aromas of bourbon, vanilla, carmel, fruittiness and light maple. Palate was medium bodied and crisp with a smooth finish. Flavors of bourbon, toffee, oak, carmel, light fruittiness and light maple with a smooth warming lingering carmel finish.

Bottle shared thanks to Scott. Pours out a dark amber color with a glass rim of a head. Aroma is of maple syrup, light alcohol, some caramel and cognac. Taste is of maple syrup, caramel, toffee, light boozy cognac, toasty earth notes, light bitterness blending with some more lingering sweetness. and a little punch of some alcohol on the finish.
Quite nice. on draft at fourth street bar. slight sweetness, nice balance of alcohol. Great off keg. will give the bottle more time though.

Bottle shared by AndyReynolds. I missed out on the local release so Im glad I got to try some.  The aroma is sweet and heavy alcohol.  The flavor is also quite sweet, heavy on the alcohol, big bourbon and maple.  Although its very forward with the bourbon and alcohol, the maple is a nice touch as it seems to mellow out the beer a bit. Its rich with lots of molasses and caramel. It goes down smoother than the aroma lets on, but stil probably best reserved as a winter warmer rather a middle of the day 80 degree beer. Interesting beer. Thanks Andy.
Pours a reddish-brown color.  Aroma is molasses, sweet syrup, light bourbon, and caramel malts.  Taste is much the same - smooth body.

Location/Date:Bottle split with Dave and Ben on March 17th, 2012.
Appearance:Pours a dark copper
Aroma: Aroma is sweet, heavy on malt
Taste: Really malt forward, boozy-bourbony, sugary, faint hops..
Palate: Medium slick body, does not hide alcohol well.
Summary: Bomber labeled "Better Half", I liked this beer but it is so booze forward its tough for me, especially on the nice warm sunny day that was last Saturday.  Well made, just maybe not for me.
Bottle.  Appearance is low because of too much sediment.  Other than that, it is a nice golden brown with this white head.  See the commercial description for the rest.  Very good.

Served from the bottle at Als of Hampden. Thanks for the chance to try this one Al.

A - Pours slightly murky copper orange with a small half finger tall off white head leaving very thin streaks of lace down part of the glass.

S - Smells of caramel, toffee, butterscotch, vanilla, oak, brown sugar and the maple syrup from the bourbon barrels. A bit of booze develops toward the end of the glass but it still smells great.

T - Starts off with lots of sweetness - mostly caramel, toffee, butterscotch, brown sugar, etc. - slowly giving way to hints of oak, vanilla and the maple syrup / bourbon from the barrels. The booze is light initially growing stronger and stronger as it sits in the glass. Finish is pretty sweet with a touch of booze burn, lingering on the pallet for some time after consumption.

M - Medium body with a rather sweet flavor and moderate carbonation. The sweetness is strong throughout, lingering long after the finish.

O - I rather enjoyed this one. It packs a ton of flavor and it was still pretty easy to drink, minus the slight booze kick. I am really starting to like all these Old Ales I have been having recently.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2012 Curmudgeons Better Half Bottle. Pours light brown with off white head. Nose/taste of baked bread, molasses, maple syrup, oak, vanilla, candi sugar, caramel, toffee, vanilla and oak. Finishes a bit "hot" and boozy. Medium body. I have a feeling this one will get better with a year or two on it.

Bottle from Rodmans DC, split with jcos and Ben4321...alcoholic maple syrup in a bottle.  Medium plus body, maple all over, pretty boozy, perhaps more than I might like.  Good beer but if you have a bottle I would suggest aging it for at least 6 months, 12 would be better.  It would get smoother and subtler and that would be a good thing.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2012 Location: Bomber at dbarnolds, 3/17/12


Aroma: The nose has some maple, bourbon/rye whiskey, vanilla, caramel, and some wood

Appearance: The pour is a caramel-orange, with a nice beige head and some light lace work

Flavor: The taste is mid-sweet, lots of caramel and vanilla, with some heavy whiskey and wood

Palate: The body is medium-plus and it has a pretty large amount of boozy burn from the 11.9%

Overall Impression: 
This was a good one.  A nice boozy offering, but it isnt so overpowering as to kill the beer.  The maple is quite present as well.  I bet it would age pretty well, but it is pretty darn good now.

Im shocked I havent rated this before because Ive had this a few times as Kaiser Curmudgeon.  750 ml bottle as Curmudgeons Better Half.   Deep ruby red pour with a small white head.  Rich aroma of caramel , toffee, maple syrup and bourbon.  Flavor is so smooth.  Mild booze.  Rich, maple syrup soaked oak, mild bourbon.  Mild sweetness balances by a light heat, rich bourbon notes.  This is an excellent beer.

Poured into a snifter from a 750ml bottle with no date.

A: Semi-hazy mahogany body with a thin off-white head.

S: Sweet maple, oak, vanilla, bourbon, and brown sugar. This is very complex and sweet.

T: Sweet molasses, oak, vanilla, and slight bourbon with a burnt brown sugar finish. This is warm, sweet, and inviting.

M: Full-bodied with very light carbonation.

O: This is a solid beer with a lot of flavors but its a bit sweet to drink a whole bottle. I recommend splitting it 2-3 ways.
This one is very sweet, maple and sugar mixed with vanilla. Way too sweet to really be enjoyed, just like drinking maple syrup and alcohol.

Aroma: roasted malt, slight caramel, molasses nose.
Appearance: Hazy, amber copper, long lasting head that is off white - tan.
Taste: Roasted malt sweetness pair very well with the molasses sweetness, little to no hop, medium carbonation.

Excellent beer, slightly overpriced at $17 per bottle but great beer on the rare occasion.

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2012 Bottle: The aroma consists of fruit punch, caramel, brown sugar, and a hint of maple syrup. Its a hazy amber with a small white head. The flavor starts with caramel, brown sugar, and chocolate. The finish has vanilla, maple syrup, light butterscotch, and a touch of mint. Its medium-full bodied with soft carbonation and mouthfeel. Overall, its tasty, buy a full bottle would wear on me quickly.

22oz bottle from 2012 release.

Pours a murky reddish-brown with a cream colored head that stood about 1 finger tall initially. If you hold it up the light, the beer actually looks more orange than anything. The light also reveals that this beer isnt nearly as hazy as I had initially though. Pretty good lacing on my snifter.

The aroma consist of bourbon, vanilla, butterscotch, ripe plums, and a little bit of wood. As it warmed I feel like Im starting to get the maple syrup in the nose as well.

Malty and sweet up front. I get a little bit of fruit and brown sugar. The bourbon shows itself in the middle and lingers through the finish with a bit of alcohol on the back end. I also get the wood/oak.

Medium..headed towards full bodied with a syrupy sweetness and a soft carbonation.

A really nice Old Ale overall.

Moreys Bottom Line: This is good, and as others have said...it does remind me of Backwoods quite a bit. Although its slightly sweeter. And the differences between the base beers (Wee Heavy vs. Old Ale) are also very noticeable.

Appearance: Pours out a near clear, medium amber body with a modestly-sized, off-white head.

Smell: Sweetish, malt-forward notes scented of caramel candy, dark brown sugar, and maple featuring supporting scents of plum jelly and oak-tinged bourbon.

Taste: Flushed with a large upfront sweetness of caramelized sugars, brown sugars, and ardent traces of maple. Well-toasted maltiness. Bourbon percolated raisins, then, a bit of zested citrus with a small portion of bitterness and a warming alcohol presence. Nuances of oak wood. Sweetish, warm (though not hot) finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-plus body. Medium carbonation.

Overall: Superb. The standard-issue Curmudgeon was a really solid beer, so this just gives it a nice little barrel-aged bump.

Pours dark amber.  Color is deceptive considering the high alcohol content of this brew.  The aroma is one of the best I have experienced, smells of maple, bourbon, and a slight yeast after taste.  This one is definitely worth trying at least once.

Aroma is sweet but subtle, appearance is an inviting amber, taste is flavorful and strong in bourbon with maple coming through second on the palate.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle at James thing. Pours dark amber/brown. Nose is rich with bourbon and maple syrup. Palate is full of booze - too much bourbon. Maple syrup is still there, along with something that I can only say made me think of sausage grease. The nice maple flavor was the saving grace of a beer that otherwise would have tasted unbalanced and sloppy.

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2012 Bottle split with friends. Pours a dark amber ice-tea body with light soapy lacing. Aroma is strong maple syrup, molasses and some booze. Mouthfeel is medium to thick with notes of molasses, maple syrup dominating, light chocolate, oak and strong booze in the finish. Another great beer from Founders.

Curmudgeons Better Half bottle at our Cellar Dip party...  Poured dark amber, slightly brown with a thin head.  Really big maple flavors, especially as it warmed.  I feared that it would be thin and watery with an unbalanced maple sweetness.  But it was the opposite.  Body was nice, sweetness was in check by strong presence of oak and alcohol warmth.
Bottle at James.  Bourbon barrell tasting.. Maple and barrel wine characteristic.  Like CBS but without the malty base.. More sweet and medium bodied.
UPDATED: MAR 30, 2012 Bottle. Pours an iced tea brown. Slight Jews. Nice mapley smell. Ridiculously smooth. Notes of slight slight chcolate with bourbon and maple. Really fantastic.

Hahaha, this is like bourbon light. Hahah, aroma is bourbon and sweetness. Straw color with a thin off white head. Huge bourbon notes with malty caramel sweetness. Rich and delicious. Body was medium, but very drinkable.

Pours a clear chestnut/ruby color with a thick foamy tan head...great retention and lacing.  Aroma has nice bourbon and sweet maple syrup...underlying vanilla and caramel notes...slightly boozy.  Flavor has lots going on...bourbon, vanilla, fig, maple, molasses, caramel...light hoppiness creeps in nicely so it doesnt taste like a sugary malt bomb...excellent.  mouthfeel is heavy and silky with a wonderful oaky finish.

I finally had the opportunity to sample this beer on tap at a local pub downtown.  Given how much Canadian Breakfast Stout absolutely lived up to the hype, at least for me, I figured this beer was more than worth sniffing out.  Luckily, my palate did not have to wait long.  The beer was served to me and my friend in two bulbous little 6 ounce snifters.  A deep, opaque amber color let little light through as the head spillled over and ran slowly down the glass, leaving a snalelike trail of sticky lacing.  Rounded notes of powdery malt, syrup, treacly vanilla and muted whiskey rose slowly from the glass to greet the nose.  The bourbon barrel flavor in this ale is nowhere near as prevalent as in Founders other BA breakfast stout offerings, KBS and CBS.  In those beers, the maple/bourbon barrel created a synergy with the chocolate and coffee that was astonishing and rich.  With the Kaiser, the maple barrel turned the beer more into a confection than anything else.  As soon as this syrupy treat hits your lips, its like youve slapped on your bib and are about to dive into a decadent pancake breakfast with LOTS of dripping, oozing syrup.  The syrupy sweet character of this beer is reigned in a bit by some flowery hops and drying vanilla notes from the barrel, but it almost goes beyond cloying.  The maple and vanilla from the barrel really come through together and finish the beer with a sticky smack, leaving some toasted malt notes to linger a while in the mouth.  Two 6 oz. pulls of this dessert in a glass were enough for me; I dont know if a third would have been worth the diabetes.  Overall, this a very comforting, warm and delightfully sticky beer with plenty to offer.  However, it doesnt round out the sweetness as much as I wanted it to and also doesnt deliver entirely on the complexity.  Perhaps my expectations were to high and inconsistent with the other Backstage offerings.  Im left wanting more out of the beer and needing to brush my teeth from the sugar.
